Prompt:
Example 1:
As Johnson worked on math problems with the other female computers, she would ask questions. She didn't want to just do the work — she wanted to know the "hows" and the "whys," and then the "why nots." By asking questions, Johnson began to stand out.
Women were not allowed to attend meetings with the male engineers and scientists. Johnson wanted to go to these meetings to learn more about the projects, so she went. She became known for her training in geometry and began to work with teams made up of men. Eventually, she was recognized as a leader, and the men increasingly relied on her to have the answers they needed.
In 1958, NACA officially became NASA. Shortly thereafter, Johnson became part of the space team. She began calculating the flight path, or trajectory path, for the rocket to put the first American in space in 1961. That American was astronaut Alan Shepard. The engineers knew when and where they wanted Shepard's space capsule to land, but the tricky part was to calculate when and where the rocket would have to launch. Johnson figured it out!

Example 2:
When Naomi saw that Ruth loved her so much, she forgot how tired and hungry she was, and the two journeyed on together until they came to Bethlehem in Judah in the beginning of the barley harvest. There was no famine in Bethlehem. The fields were full of waving grain, and busy servants were reaping it and gathering it up to bind into sheaves. Above all were the fields of the rich man, Boaz, shining with barley and corn.
Naomi and Ruth came to the edge of the fields and watched the busy reapers. They saw that after each sheaf was bound, and each pile of corn was stacked, a little grain fell, unnoticed, to the ground. Ruth said to Naomi: "Let me go to the field and glean the ears of corn after them." And Naomi said to her, "Go, my daughter." And she went, and came and gleaned in the field after the reapers.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'nutrition' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 150 words. 

Nutrition is the study of food. It's how our bodies get the energy we need to run around and play. Food gives us the strength to learn, to grow, and to feel happy. There are many kinds of food that are good for us. Fruits and vegetables are full of vitamins and minerals that help us stay healthy. Grains like bread and pasta give us carbohydrates, which help us have the energy we need to move around. Protein from foods like chicken and beans help us build strong muscles. We should eat a variety of foods to get the nutrients we need. A good rule of thumb is to eat foods in every color of the rainbow. This will help us stay healthy and strong. So, let's make a plan to eat a healthy diet and give our bodies the fuel they need to thrive. By doing so, we can be our best selves.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'nutrition' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 150 words. 

The human body is a machine that needs fuel to run. This fuel is called nutrition. The food we eat gives us the energy we need to think, move, and grow. But not all foods are created equal. Some foods are like gasoline, they give us quick energy but they can also be bad for us. Other foods are like diesel, they take a little longer to give us energy but they are better for us in the long run. Fruits, vegetables, and whole grains are like diesel. They have fiber, vitamins, and minerals that help keep us healthy. If we eat a balanced diet with a variety of foods, we will have the energy to do all the things we want to do. By eating healthy, we will be able to run, jump, and play without getting tired easily. We will be able to focus and learn new things. We will be able to grow strong and healthy. Nutrition is important for our bodies. It helps us to be our best selves

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'nutrition' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 150 words. 

Eating a balanced diet is essential for nutrition. But what does that really mean? A diet is the food that we eat. It's like a special recipe that includes a variety of foods to keep our bodies healthy. Foods are divided into four groups: fruits, vegetables, grains, and proteins. Each group has its own set of benefits. Fruits are packed with vitamins and minerals, while vegetables provide fiber and antioxidants. Grains are rich in complex carbohydrates, and proteins are made up of building blocks called amino acids. By mixing all these groups together, we can create a balanced diet. This will give us the energy to run, play, and grow strong. Just like Ruth, who was willing to work hard in the fields, we too must be willing to make the effort to eat well and stay healthy. By choosing the right foods, we can reap the rewards of a healthy lifestyle.

The sun was shining, and the garden was full of life. There were fruits and vegetables growing everywhere. Among them were apples, carrots, and leafy greens. In the beginning of the harvest, the fields were full of crops. The farmers would reap the crops and gather them up to bind into bunches. Above all were the fields of the rich farmer, Mr. Thompson, shining with fresh produce. The busy farmhands were reaping the crops, and little by little, they would drop some of the crops to the ground. Emma said to her mom, "Let me go to the garden and gather some of the crops that have fallen to the ground." And her mom said, "Go, Emma." And she went, and came and gathered some of the fresh fruits and vegetables to make a healthy salad. By eating the right foods, Emma would have the energy to play outside all day.

A person's body is like a machine, and food is its fuel. The "fuel" gives the body the energy it needs to run, just like gasoline gives a car the power to move. Good fuel helps the body work well. Just like how a car needs the right kind of gasoline, the body needs the right kind of food to stay healthy. That's why people eat a variety of foods, such as fruits, vegetables, and grains. The body uses these foods to build strong muscles and keep the heart beating well. A healthy body is like a well-tuned machine, and eating the right foods is like putting in the right fuel. By doing this, a person can feel happy and have lots of energy to play and have fun. Good nutrition is very important for a healthy body and mind.

Prompt:
Example 1:
As Johnson worked on math problems with the other female computers, she would ask questions. She didn't want to just do the work — she wanted to know the "hows" and the "whys," and then the "why nots." By asking questions, Johnson began to stand out.
Women were not allowed to attend meetings with the male engineers and scientists. Johnson wanted to go to these meetings to learn more about the projects, so she went. She became known for her training in geometry and began to work with teams made up of men. Eventually, she was recognized as a leader, and the men increasingly relied on her to have the answers they needed.
In 1958, NACA officially became NASA. Shortly thereafter, Johnson became part of the space team. She began calculating the flight path, or trajectory path, for the rocket to put the first American in space in 1961. That American was astronaut Alan Shepard. The engineers knew when and where they wanted Shepard's space capsule to land, but the tricky part was to calculate when and where the rocket would have to launch. Johnson figured it out!

Example 2:
When Naomi saw that Ruth loved her so much, she forgot how tired and hungry she was, and the two journeyed on together until they came to Bethlehem in Judah in the beginning of the barley harvest. There was no famine in Bethlehem. The fields were full of waving grain, and busy servants were reaping it and gathering it up to bind into sheaves. Above all were the fields of the rich man, Boaz, shining with barley and corn.
Naomi and Ruth came to the edge of the fields and watched the busy reapers. They saw that after each sheaf was bound, and each pile of corn was stacked, a little grain fell, unnoticed, to the ground. Ruth said to Naomi: "Let me go to the field and glean the ears of corn after them." And Naomi said to her, "Go, my daughter." And she went, and came and gleaned in the field after the reapers.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'nutrition' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 150 words. 

When Sarah learned that her family loved to cook and eat healthy meals, she wanted to know more about nutrition. She started by watching her mom prepare vegetables for dinner, and asking questions. She wanted to know the "hows" and the "whys," and then the "why nots." By asking questions, Sarah began to understand how different foods affected her body. She learned that fruits and vegetables are good sources of vitamins and minerals, and that whole grains provide fiber and energy. Sarah became interested in nutrition and started to help her mom plan healthy meals. She even began to read books and articles about nutrition. As she learned more, Sarah felt proud of herself and her family for making healthy choices. Sarah's love for learning about nutrition was contagious, and soon her family and friends were interested in healthy eating too.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'nutrition' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 150 words. 

What is nutrition? Nutrition is the way that the body gets what it needs to work properly. Food is the main source of nutrition. Different foods provide different nutrients. Fruits, vegetables, and whole grains give the body fiber, which helps it digest food. Protein from meat, beans, and nuts helps build strong muscles. Vitamin D from sunlight helps build strong bones. Minerals from food help our bodies work properly. Eating a balanced diet is essential for good health. A balanced diet is one that includes a variety of foods from different food groups. This will give the body all the nutrients it needs to function properly. When we eat well, we have more energy and feel happy and healthy.

The paragraph is designed to be easy to understand and to convey the importance of a balanced diet. The vocabulary and structure are inspired by examples 1 and 2.
